displayed_text: Patient: The Xgeva, we stopped. Doctor: Enzalutamide, you’re still taking four pills a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: The only drug that you’ve got on here -- Patient: for two weeks and two weeks off. Doctor: You got your hormone shot - the lisinopril five milligrams a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: And a multi-vitamin? Patient: Once a day. Doctor: Any other medicine that you’d add to this or take off this list? (pause) Patient: Nope. (pause) Doctor: And you don’t get your treat – your hormone shot here, right?

Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: He’ll probably tell you on that day – Family Member: Uh huh. Doctor: When you’re likely to get… Do you have anything going on that you want us to work around then let them know at that time? Patient: That we probably can’t change. Doctor: Okay. Patient: The doctors you know. Doctor: Oh doctors, okay. Payments. Because then I was gonna say get that done before we start this whole process. Doctor: Okay so let me let them know okay and then you can leave but we’ll schedule the appointment with me and all that afterwards Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah.and probably Dr. C____ and I will see you same day like we did today. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? I love that color on you today.

Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now. Doctor: Yeah Patient: But the quality of life has been reasonably good. Doctor: That’s- Yeah. That’s that’s the best part to hear. Absolutely. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Good. Patient: So I mean it’s just um and then I had um breakfast with this guy who is a couple years ahead of me in high school and he…

Patient: Uh, it is still ain’t where I want it. You know? It’s like it’s, it be trying. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know? And, and, uh, sometimes it don’t, but, you know, I be feeling like it’s trying. Yeah. Doctor: Did you talk to Dr. D___ about it? Patient: No. I didn’t. No. I didn’t go. I just, I just said that I’m just going to be patient and just let things, you know, just keep doing what you’re telling me to do. And I still been taking the pills. Doctor: You’re taking the pills? Patient: Yes. Um hum. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: Well, so. Doctor: Alright. You know, we can, there are other options there for you. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Are you able to have an erection at all with the pills?

Patient: Fine. Doctor: Okay. Good to see you. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: A ___ may want you to fill out something, so. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yeah and where will I get the form for the appointment? Doctor: When you head out front, along that purple wall there there’s people there. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It should be pretty clean and nobody out there now. There might be somebody there and there may not be. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, let me see if A ___ needs to see you before you go. Patient: Okay. Do you have some paperclips? That’s fine. Okay.

Patient: That’s it. Doctor: Just the catheters. Family Member: Because he was improving; results were uh coming in. You know kidneys back into you know. Patient: They were getting better everyday, yeah. Doctor: They adjusted your blood pressure medicine. Patient: Correct. That is one thing that they did. They said the first time it was not good for the kidneys. Family Member: Actually when you came out it was two point two. And then a week later we went to see his uh - Patient: General practitioner and - Family Member: So what is the reading today? Doctor: One point zero. Family Member: Wow! Doctor: So that is what it’s supposed to be. A new one. (background noise persists in addition to keyboarding sounds)

Patient: I - at this point I think you all are taking pretty good care of me. So that means a lot to me and so, but I will touch base with him. Family Member: So this, I know it’s not cure. But you mentioned, you said remission a couple of times. What constitutes remission when you’re speaking of cancer? Doctor: Remission means that the cancer disappears completely. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Or partially. So the complete remission would mean that the PSA level goes to zero. Family Member: Is that something that could possibly happen in this case? Doctor: With the hormone therapy—yes. Family Member: With the hormone therapy—yes. Doctor: It happens frequently. Now it’s a bit misleading because it’s not truly zero. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s below the limit of detection, so the laboratory for example is below zero point one milligrams per ml. Family Member: Uh hum.

Family Member: Hormones - Uh is he getting more medicine today? Doctor: Well he got that shot; that shot lasts for three months Family Member: OHH! Patient: For three months? Oh, okay. I thought it was for three weeks. Doctor: Three months. Patient: Three months. Family Member: Three months. So at what point does the prostate shrink? Doctor: That’s our hope. Family Member: OHH! Patient: So should I be wearing this catheter for a while then? Doctor: Well because again it could be as early as this week that they feel like you can pee on your own. But if that’s what they’re going to be testing - Patient: And they cannot test it any other way except by pulling it out.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know, I’m sorry. Patient: And you would recommend that at least at a minimum? Doctor: Well, you know there’s two ways to approach this. We could wait until you really are in trouble. And in trouble would mean you have a fever, you have no white cells, you better come in to the hospital, you need antibiotics. Patient: Yeah I don’t know (stammering) Doctor: But you’ve already demonstrated that your cells go down. You know you weren’t doing great. I just think we’re asking for trouble. So I’ve tried to explain that and they’re like is it a fever with no white cells. That’s all the understand. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know (sighs) Patient: Because I don’t mind making a phone call either but probably me stay out or what do you think? Doctor: Yeah it’s gonna be all how we code and get them… Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: So at this point anyway now that we’re in here now okay this is… Doctor: This is it.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: and that almost yielded nothing either. You had like one abnormality at zero point one percent as in I don’t think you have much floating around which is kind of good but nothing that we can sort of target. Patient: Yeah, Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, we got a target something? Doctor: Well, I think we… Patient: Got to find out if we… Doctor: Exactly. Patient: We got to find out. Doctor: So, you guys now are on the same page as me in terms of what to expect after the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I never order stuff when it’s, I don’t want it to be a mystery. You guys should know exactly what we’re going to do depending on the results. Patient: Okay. I like that.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we’re pacing you. Mm,hmm. Family Member: So, we’ve got four or five more chemos… Doctor: Yeah I think… Family Member: And then we’ll do a scan? Patient: Did you count this as one? Doctor: That was one. So I think we just need to sort of… Patient: This would be two. Doctor: Yeah. We’ll do three more of this um because again there’s a little interruption, there’s radiation, you know so we’ll just do four total Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Did you make a comment once that um that chemo doesn’t go up the skull or up to the brain or something like that? Doctor: It doesn’t typically penetrate to go to brain tissue, but it will penetrate to skull because that’s part of the bone.

Patient: But it seemed like I, would have, I was degenerating pretty quickly for you know? For all the bone scans I’ve had… Doctor: Yeah. Yes. Patient: Somebody would have seen that somewhere. Doctor: No. I think it’s just crappy cancer not controlled. You know? Patient: And Uh. Yeah. Doctor: There’s, there’s the uh oh this is really going to be in trouble. We got that fixed. But it’s the bigger picture. Patient: You know uh you know and I feel I actually am you know doc I’m not running today but I’m getting around better. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I’ve, I’ve seen the, you know the steady increase. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Uh, you know, little dips on certain days. Doctor: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh) Doctor: So I still think they are because, but what this says is that there is increasing uptake. So since I’m gonna give you these… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: …I wanted you to know. Unfortunately the size are the how bright it is. So increasing uptake means it’s brighter now than it was before. Patient: This is in the bones? Doctor: Correct, yeah. That grade of brightness I guess, doesn’t mean a whole lot for prostate cancer on the bone scan. Okay because even healing bone can look brighter than the other. So on the bone scan really what would tell me that there is progression of the disease would be if there were new areas and there were not. Okay? But I just needed to explain this because- Family Member: Yes. Patient: -- of this is what the scan report is gonna read which I’m gonna give you right now. So this – but the same areas were the lower back and the left hip, the hip bones, so those are the two main areas. Family Member: And the rib or not the rib? Doctor: The ribs are still there and we are following it. It’s in the left side on the sixth rib. Yeah I mean that also was there before Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: and that stayed about the same. Family Member: But the increased uptake is in the lower back and the left hip?

Patient: I see. Doctor: All the things it does downstream without the ball. We’ve been testing that as part of this trial. So I need to dig into the group that’s testing and find out are you one of those guys that was positive? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you were positive, that would mean pretty strongly that we shouldn’t try more hormone treatments. You need to be positive for that to go on this immune trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh they’re looking for folks who might have more aggressive hormone insensitive cases. So I’m, I’m going to do that this week just to find out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so I think that’s a trial. Uh I’m trying to think. I mean, we, we had a, I’m just thinking of one of the study nurses. There’s also some evidence that folks who uh have been on enzalutamide like you are, there was a group that started giving people immune therapy with enzalutamide, even though the enzalutamide was not working. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They kept them on the enzalutamide and added this immune drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And they had occasional patients who have very dramatic effects. Uh probably about twenty-five percent of the patients they treat. So we have a trial. I’ve got to figure out if we can finesse it because you’re not on enzalutamide any more.

Family Member: And if that happens, what if all of a sudden he spikes a fever and it happens at night, uh - Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah, that’s right. No, one-eight hundred _____. That is like a twenty-four-hour line. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You can do it yourself, but then you’re flustered. It’s a little bit complicated, - Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s why I prefer; you know I tell people - Patient: Right, yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: to just you may want use that one-eight hundred number. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: It’s easier. It takes away the fact of you having to follow the instructions. Family Member: All right. Doctor: And that is on my card if you really want to use that.
